elements.content: On the basis of the XRPD, ab initio, and EXAFS refined geometries, as summarized in the right parts of Tables , and , a comparative discussion of the structural results obtained with the three approaches can be faced. According to what was discussed for the hydroxylated case (), ab initio distances were averaged differently in order to be directly comparable with XRPD or EXAFS results. For symmetry reasons, XRPD refined three equivalent μ3−O distances at 2.107 Å, in fair agreement with ab initio results (2.116 Å). Such a value comes from averaging two short (μ3−Oa and μ3−Ob) and a long distance (μ3−Oc), the latter being sufficiently stretched (2.237 Å) to fall in the region of the Zr−O1 distances. For this reason, EXAFS refinement gives a much shorter R μ3−O value (2.06 Å) that is, however, in perfect agreement with the average of the R μ3−Oa and R μ3−Ob values refined in the ab initio calculations (2.056 Å). Coming from the distances with the four oxygen atoms of the carboxylate units, XRPD, ab initio, and EXAFS results in R O1 values of 2.233, 2.221, and 2.221 Å, respectively, the latter value also including the longer μ3−Oc distance. An excellent agreement is obtained by XRPD and ab initio in determining the distance with the C atoms of the carboxylate units: 3.255 and 3.241 Å, respectively. EXAFS refinement is unable to reproduce correctly the R C1 value (3.17 Å) because of a destructive interference with some MS paths as outlined at the end of the . The high symmetry of the XRPD model imposes a single octahedron side R Zr1 = 3.510 Å that agrees well with the averaged value coming from EXAFS approach: 3.48 Å. Ab initio and EXAFS approaches, that are able to observe the splitting of the octahedron edges (but with different degeneration), agree on the long value (R Zr1b = 3.736 and 3.74 Å, respectively), while disagree significantly on shorter one (R Zr1a = 3.462 and 3.35 Å, respectively). Finally, the octahedron diagonal is estimated to be R Zr2 = 4.964 and 5.093 Å for the XRPD and ab initio approaches, respectively. EXAFS is the only technique that, having no symmetry constrain, is able to observe the octahedron diagonal splitting. Optimized values are R Zr2a = 4.14 ± 0.07 Å (N Zr2a =1/3) and R Zr2b = 5.30 ± 0.04 Å (N Zr2b =2/3), respectively. The average value <R Zr2> = 4.91 Å is in fair agreement with the XRPD distance (4.964 Å), while is significantly underestimated with respect to the ab initio value (5.093 Å). Comparison with the geometrical consideration is very good: expected R Zr2b = (2 R Zr1b)1/2 = 5.29 and R Zr2a = [4 R 2 Zr1b − R 2 Zr2b]1/2 = 4.11 Å, meaning that the model of the axially squeezed Zr6 octahedron (Figure c) is fully compatible with the EXAFS data. It must however be considered that this model is highly supported by the EXAFS analysis of the side lengths (as the EXAFS signal associated with R Zr1a and R Zr1b SS paths is strong), while the additional agreement obtained by analyzing the much weaker diagonal signal, although elegant, adds only little significance to the model.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of the XRPD, ab initio, and EXAFS refined geometries, as summarized in the right parts of Tables ,  and , a comparative discussion of the structural results obtained with the three approaches can be faced. According to what was discussed for the hydroxylated case (), ab initio distances were averaged differently in order to be directly comparable with XRPD or EXAFS results. For symmetry reasons, XRPD refined three equivalent μ3-O distances at 2.107 Å, in fair agreement with ab initio results (2.116 Å). Such a value comes from averaging two short (μ3-Oa and μ3-Ob) and a long distance (μ3-Oc), the latter being sufficiently stretched (2.237 Å) to fall in the region of the Zr-O1 distances. For this reason, EXAFS refinement gives a much shorter R μ3-O value (2.06 Å) that is, however, in perfect agreement with the average of the R μ3-Oa and R μ3-Ob values refined in the ab initio calculations (2.056 Å). Coming from the distances with the four oxygen atoms of the carboxylate units, XRPD, ab initio, and EXAFS results in R O1 values of 2.233, 2.221, and 2.221 Å, respectively, the latter value also including the longer μ3-Oc distance. An excellent agreement is obtained by XRPD and ab initio in determining the distance with the C atoms of the carboxylate units: 3.255 and 3.241 Å, respectively. EXAFS refinement is unable to reproduce correctly the R C1 value (3.17 Å) because of a destructive interference with some MS paths as outlined at the end of the . The high symmetry of the XRPD model imposes a single octahedron side R Zr1 = 3.510 Å that agrees well with the averaged value coming from EXAFS approach: 3.48 Å. Ab initio and EXAFS approaches, that are able to observe the splitting of the octahedron edges (but with different degeneration), agree on the long value (R Zr1b = 3.736 and 3.74 Å, respectively), while disagree significantly on shorter one (R Zr1a = 3.462 and 3.35 Å, respectively). Finally, the octahedron diagonal is estimated to be R Zr2 = 4.964 and 5.093 Å for the XRPD and ab initio approaches, respectively. EXAFS is the only technique that, having no symmetry constrain, is able to observe the octahedron diagonal splitting. Optimized values are R Zr2a = 4.14 ± 0.07 Å (N Zr2a =1/3) and R Zr2b = 5.30 ± 0.04 Å (N Zr2b =2/3), respectively. The average value <R Zr2> = 4.91 Å is in fair agreement with the XRPD distance (4.964 Å), while is significantly underestimated with respect to the ab initio value (5.093 Å). Comparison with the geometrical consideration is very good: expected R Zr2b = (2 R Zr1b)1/2 = 5.29 and R Zr2a = [4 R 2 Zr1b - R 2 Zr2b]1/2 = 4.11 Å, meaning that the model of the axially squeezed Zr6 octahedron (Figure c) is fully compatible with the EXAFS data. It must however be considered that this model is highly supported by the EXAFS analysis of the side lengths (as the EXAFS signal associated with R Zr1a and R Zr1b SS paths is strong), while the additional agreement obtained by analyzing the much weaker diagonal signal, although elegant, adds only little significance to the model.

elements.clean_text:
Vibrational and Electronic Properties: Experimental versus ab initio Results

IR Characterization of the Lattice Vibration: Effect of Solvent Removal and Rehydration

IR spectroscopy can be of great help in the characterization of MOF materials. The IR spectra reported in Figure  summarizes the effect on the vibrational properties of solvent removal and progressive dehydration (top part) and successive rehydration (bottom part) of UiO-66. Panels (a) and (b) refer to the OH and framework stretching modes, respectively. For sake of simplicity, we will discuss panel (a) and panel (b) separately, even if the data were collected simultaneously in the two spectral ranges.

elements.content: (a): Effect of dehydration (top parts) and rehydration (bottom parts) on the IR curves in the O−H stretching region; curve 1 (as-prepared sample), curve 2 outgassed at room temperature 1′, curve 3 outgassed at room temperature 10′, curve 4 outgassed at 150 °C for 30 min, curve 5 outgassed at 250 °C for 30 min, curve 6 outgassed at 300 °C for 30 min, and curves 7−14 effect of progressive rehydration (curve 14 was collected after 8 h). (b): As panel (a) in the skeletal modes region. (c): Computed IR spectra of hydrated (blue) and dehydrated (red) forms, optimized in the F-43m and R-3 space groups, respectively. Experimental (panel b) and computed (panel c) spectra were reported on the same wavenumber range and scale to allow direct comparison. No scaling factor has been adopted.

Experimental (panel b) and computed (panel c) spectra were reported on the same wavenumber range and scale to allow direct comparison. No scaling factor has been adopted.

elements.content: Bold black curve in panel (a) of Figure illustrates the IR spectrum of a thin film of the UiO-66 sample, prepared by deposition on a silicon wafer of Zr−MOF sample placed in water suspension. The spectrum is dominated by an intense and broad band centered at 3450 cm−1 due to intercrystallite water (used for preparing the deposition) and physisorbed water condensed inside the crystal cavities. A minor but much sharper component at 3675 cm−1 corresponds to a small fraction of isolated OH groups (mainly present on the external surfaces of the microcrystals), while in the 3100−2850 cm−1 interval weak bands due to aromatic and aliphatic ν(C−H) modes of benzene ring and DMF are visible. The effect of progressive outgassing at room temperature (1 and 10 min), 150 °C and at 250 °C is illustrated by red curves 2−5, respectively. The relevant decrease of the band centered at 3450 cm−1, upon an outgassing of 1 min at room temperatrure (curve 2) is mainly due to removal of intercrystallite water; parallel growth of the component due to isolated OH groups (sharp peak at 3672 cm−1) present on the external surfaces is also observed. Successive outgassing for increased time (curve 3) and heating (curves 4−5 until 250 °C) erodes nearly completely the band at 3450 cm−1 and causes the growth of the peak at 3672 cm−1. A thermal treatment in high vacuo for 30 min at 300 °C gives rise to the red curve reported in panel (a) of Figure . In this case, very few OH groups are left, and only weak bands due to the CH modes are present. Rehydration effects on the IR spectra of Zr−MOF are illustrated in the bottom part of panel (a) of Figure , curves 6−14. The last spectrum was obtained after 8 h (black curve dashed dotted). Under these conditions, UiO-66 is progressively rehydrated (growth of the peak at 3672 cm−1 and of band centered at 3450 cm−1). The uncompleted restoration of spectrum 1 (full line black curve) is due by the fact that it was obtained on a sample soaked in water, while only vapor tension is dosed on the rehydration step.

The high stability of the framework with respect to water solvent (already tested by XRPD, see Figure S2a of the ) is confirmed by IR data that show complete reversibility of the dehydration/hydration phenomenon. The IR spectra reported at the bottom part of panel (b) of Figure testify that the spectrum obtained upon rehydration is completely equivalent to that collected on the starting sample (compare black curves full line and dashed dotted lines).

elements.content: The black curve in panel (b) of Figure reports the IR spectrum in the skeletal modes region of the as-prepared sample. The band at 1667 cm−1 is ascribed to DMF, while the intense doublet at 1589 and 1395 cm−1 is associated to the in- and out-of-phase stretching modes of the carboxylate group. At lower frequencies, modes due to OH and CH bending are mixed with Zr−O modes (main bands at 746, 726, 702, 683, 614, 556, and 475 cm−1). In ZrO2, a triplet at 725, 620, and 530 cm−1 was assigned to longitudinal and transverse modes, respectively. Upon a progressive outgassing (spectra 2−6) the main changes observed can be summarized as follows: (i) disappearance of the band at 1667 cm−1 due to DMF, (ii) perturbation of the carboxylates modes, in particular the asymmetric component decreases in intensity and blue shifts, and (iii) substantial changes in the 800−400 cm−1 interval, where the peak at 746 cm−1 grows, the bands at 726, 702, 683 cm−1 disappear, the component at 556 cm−1 decreases in intensity and a new component appears at 526 cm−1, while the band at 475 cm−1 shifts to 502 cm−1 becoming less intense and broader. The substantial changes in the skeletal modes of UiO-66 that occur upon activation at 300 °C can be justified by considering the relevant distortion of the Zr6O4(OH)4 cluster that rearranges into a distorted Zr6O6 cluster (Figure ). In previous studies on other MOF materials, modifications of the framework vibrational features upon solvent removal have already been observed and justified by the rearrangement of the structure upon water removal. In this case, however, the changes are more relevant as the extraction of two out of the eight μ3−O of the inorganic clusters occurs. Structural data have shown that the removal of bridging μ3−OH groups causes a relevant loss in the local symmetry of the units (). This has an effect on the vibrational properties as illustrated in panel (c) of Figure that compares the computed IR spectra at the B3LYP level of theory in the case of hydroxylated and dehydroxylated sample (blue and red curves, respectively). In particular, note the fate of the band at 673 cm−1, associated to μ3−O stretching, that shifts up to 730 cm−1 in the case of the dehydroxylated material and the disappearance of the component at 470 cm−1 ascribed to the (HO)−Zr−(OH) bending mode. Experimental and computed spectra are in very good agreement, thus allowing an assignment of the main observed IR peaks. Selected calculated vibrational frequencies and the description of the corresponding normal modes are reported in Table . Modes animation can be visualized at the CRYSTAL Web site.

elements.content: DRS UV−vis spectra of hydroxylated and dehydroxylated UiO-66 are compared in panel (a) of Figure , blue and red curves, respectively. Spectra of disodium terephthalate (gray curve) and of bulk ZrO2 (green curve) are also reported for sake of comparison (Table ). UiO-66 spectra are characterized by an absorption edge around 310 nm ascribed to π−π* electronic transitions of the aromatic ring. The red shift, with respect to the π−π* transitions of benzene, is a consequence of the conjugation with the two carboxylate groups, as testified by the spectrum of the terephtalate (gray curve). Electronic transitions involving the metal cluster are not visible as they occur at much higher energy: ZrO2 (green curve) spectrum shows an edge at 239 nm, associated to O2−Zr4+ → O−Zr3+ LCMT transition. Sample activation induces a small blue shift of the edge that moves from 305 to 315 nm.

Material Band Gap UV-Vis and Electrostatic Potential

DRS UV-vis spectra of hydroxylated and dehydroxylated UiO-66 are compared in panel (a) of Figure , blue and red curves, respectively. Spectra of disodium terephthalate (gray curve) and of bulk ZrO2 (green curve) are also reported for sake of comparison (Table ). UiO-66 spectra are characterized by an absorption edge around 310 nm ascribed to π-π* electronic transitions of the aromatic ring. The red shift, with respect to the π-π* transitions of benzene, is a consequence of the conjugation with the two carboxylate groups, as testified by the spectrum of the terephtalate (gray curve). Electronic transitions involving the metal cluster are not visible as they occur at much higher energy: ZrO2 (green curve) spectrum shows an edge at 239 nm, associated to O2-Zr4+ → O-Zr3+ LCMT transition. Sample activation induces a small blue shift of the edge that moves from 305 to 315 nm.

Plane wave pseudopotential fixing the lattice parameters at the experimental values.

Vacuum UV spectroscopy.

On a computational ground, the energy gap (E g) was computed first for the three forms of ZrO2 to verify the validity of the adopted level of theory. In agreement with the results of Kralik et al., who adopted a plane wave approach, we found that the zirconia E g increases in the order of monoclinic < cubic < tetragonal (Table ). Comparison with the experimental E g value for the monoclinic phase results in an overestimation of about 22%, confirming the general overestimation of E g computed at B3LYP level.

elements.content: The experimental shift of E g, undergone by UiO-66 by dehydroxylation, is confirmed by the calculated values that lower from 272 nm (4.56 eV) to 296 nm (4.19 eV) (see right parts of Figure b,c and Table ). From the analysis of the density of states projected on the different atoms of the framework (see left parts of Figure b,c), the origin of the band gap tuning upon dehydroxylation is disclosed. In both hydroxylated and dehydroxylated cases, the carbon atoms of the organic linker are those involved in the modulation of the band gaps, while Zr atoms do not play any role. This result is similar to that obtained for MOF-5 structure.

From the analysis of the density of states projected on the different atoms of the framework (see left parts of Figure b,c), the origin of the band gap tuning upon dehydroxylation is disclosed. This result is similar to that obtained for MOF-5 structure.

elements.content: Interestingly, the E g of UiO-66 and MOF-5 show different behaviors with respect to those of their corresponding oxides (i.e., ZrO2 and ZnO). For MOF-5, the presence of valence electronic bands in the gap due to the organic linkers leads to an increase of the computed E g (from 3.4 eV for ZnO to 5.0 eV), while for UiO-66 this causes an E g reduction (from 6.3 to 4.5 eV). Consequently, the role of the organic linker to define the band gap of the MOF suggests that its functionalization and/or interaction with adsorbed molecules are a mean to tune MOF’s band gaps, opening a way for optical and sensoring applications.

elements.content: The electrostatic potential was calculated and mapped on a charge density iso-surface of 0.003 |e|. Three-dimensional maps are reported in panels (d) and (e) of Figure for the hydroxylated and dehydroxylated UiO-66 structures, respectively. Red, green, and blue regions represent negative, zero, and positive values, respectively. In panel (d), a prominent neutral zone (green spot) shows up corresponding to the hydrogen atom in the inorganic brick of the hydroxylated system. Nevertheless, in both pictures, the positive areas around the zirconium atom (blue spots) are very similar, while the negative zone (red spots) in panel (d) looks stronger than in panel (e). Comparison between panels (d) and (e) allows for a qualitative view on the electronic rearrangement undergone by the Zr6O4(OH)4 unit upon dehydroxylation. On top of this, such qualitative pictures can be of help in the identification of preferential adsorption sites for small molecules; nevertheless, in the present case, the high packing of the Zr6O4(OH)4 and Zr6O7 units (that are linked to 12 BDC units) do not allow access to the metal centers. Molecular adsorption is then expected to occur mainly on the BDC linkers.

elements.content: We reported a detailed study of the structural, vibrational, and electronic features of UiO-66 (Zr-BDC MOF) in its hydroxylated and dehydroxylated forms as obtained through the combination of experimental and theoretical approaches such as XRPD, EXAFS, IR, and UV−vis spectroscopies and ab initio periodic DFT calculations. This knowledge is important because the determined thermal stability of this MOF and its resistance to aggressive chemical solvents, makes UiO-66 a potential candidate for practical applications, e. g., in catalysis or photocatalysis.
elements.clean_text:
Summary and Conclusions

We reported a detailed study of the structural, vibrational, and electronic features of UiO-66 (Zr-BDC MOF) in its hydroxylated and dehydroxylated forms as obtained through the combination of experimental and theoretical approaches such as XRPD, EXAFS, IR, and UV-vis spectroscopies and ab initio periodic DFT calculations. This knowledge is important because the determined thermal stability of this MOF and its resistance to aggressive chemical solvents, makes UiO-66 a potential candidate for practical applications, e. g., in catalysis or photocatalysis.

elements.content: The stability properties of UiO-66 were outlined in details: temperature-dependent XRPD was performed to confirm the crystallinity of the material in air up to 375 °C, and thermo-gravimetric analysis, that showed a progressive structured weigh loss up to 300 °C, was combined with mass spectroscopy experiment to confirm the loss of physisorbed water first and DMF molecules afterward. More than 70% of the starting weight was reported to be still preserved up to 500 °C, where loss of benzene fragments starts and the structure collapses leaving a low crystalline ZrO2. An accurate determination of the weight loss at this final stage, allowed an estimation of the material defectivity, measuring the drift of the BDC/Zr6O4(OH)4 ratio from 12. Stability was checked with respect to water, benzene, acetone, ethanol, a strong acid such as HCl, and a strong base as NaOH.
elements.clean_text: The stability properties of UiO-66 were outlined in details: temperature-dependent XRPD was performed to confirm the crystallinity of the material in air up to 375 °C, and thermo-gravimetric analysis, that showed a progressive structured weigh loss up to 300 °C, was combined with mass spectroscopy experiment to confirm the loss of physisorbed water first and DMF molecules afterward. More than 70% of the starting weight was reported to be still preserved up to 500 °C, where loss of benzene fragments starts and the structure collapses leaving a low crystalline ZrO2. An accurate determination of the weight loss at this final stage, allowed an estimation of the material defectivity, measuring the drift of the BDC/Zr6O4(OH)4 ratio from 12. Stability was checked with respect to water, benzene, acetone, ethanol, a strong acid such as HCl, and a strong base as NaOH.

elements.content: The structure of both hydroxylated and dehydroxylated forms was refined through an interactive XRPD/EXAFS approach. The different evolution of the XRPD pattern and EXAFS spectra upon solvent removal was described in detail, showing how the material evolves differently on local and long-range levels. Solvent removal implies the loss of structural μ3−OH groups from the ordered Zr6O4(OH)4 cluster into a distorted Zr6O6 cluster, i.e., from T d (−43 m) to D 3d (−3 m) symmetry. Zr atoms changes from 8- to 7-fold coordination. IR spectra confirmed the full removal of OH groups. The final accepted models satisfied both XRPD and EXAFS evidence and were used as input for periodic ab initio calculation to further verify the validity of the structures.
elements.clean_text: The structure of both hydroxylated and dehydroxylated forms was refined through an interactive XRPD/EXAFS approach. The different evolution of the XRPD pattern and EXAFS spectra upon solvent removal was described in detail, showing how the material evolves differently on local and long-range levels. Solvent removal implies the loss of structural μ3-OH groups from the ordered Zr6O4(OH)4 cluster into a distorted Zr6O6 cluster, i.e., from T d (-43 m) to D 3d (-3 m) symmetry. Zr atoms changes from 8- to 7-fold coordination. IR spectra confirmed the full removal of OH groups. The final accepted models satisfied both XRPD and EXAFS evidence and were used as input for periodic ab initio calculation to further verify the validity of the structures.

elements.content: For both forms of UiO-66, ab initio structural distances were compared with XRPD and EXAFS data separately to take into account that the distances obtained by the two experimental techniques are different in systems where local and long-range order behave differently. For this reason, distances obtained at B3LYP level were averaged differently when compared with the experimental XRPD and EXAFS values (Tables Table , respectively).
elements.clean_text: For both forms of UiO-66, ab initio structural distances were compared with XRPD and EXAFS data separately to take into account that the distances obtained by the two experimental techniques are different in systems where local and long-range order behave differently. For this reason, distances obtained at B3LYP level were averaged differently when compared with the experimental XRPD and EXAFS values (Tables  Table , respectively).

elements.content: Hydroxylated case: EXAFS and ab initio techniques agreed in the determination of the μ3−O distance, while XRPD (not able to discriminate between R μ3−O and R μ3−OH) overestimated it; on the other hand, calculated R O1 distances agreed with those observed by XRPD, while EXAFS, merging μ3−OH and O1, overestimated them. Observed R Zr1 and R Zr2 were very similar, showing a 1.5% disagreement with respect to the calculated result.
elements.clean_text: Hydroxylated case: EXAFS and ab initio techniques agreed in the determination of the μ3-O distance, while XRPD (not able to discriminate between R μ3-O and R μ3-OH) overestimated it; on the other hand, calculated R O1 distances agreed with those observed by XRPD, while EXAFS, merging μ3-OH and O1, overestimated them. Observed R Zr1 and R Zr2 were very similar, showing a 1.5% disagreement with respect to the calculated result.

elements.content: Dehydroxylated case: For XRPD, three equivalent Rμ3−O exist that well matched with ab initio results (able to take into complete account the symmetry breaking of the system). In this case, EXAFS saw only two out of three μ3−O distances that, nevertheless, agreed very nicely with the calculated one; the remaining R μ3−O laid in the range of the four oxygen atoms of the carboxylate units, leading to an average value slightly smaller than those obtained with XRPD and ab initio approaches that agreed better. Coming to the metallic distances, ab initio and EXAFS, both were able to observe the splitting of the octahedron edges and agreed on the long value (R Zr1b), while they disagreed on the shorter one (R Zr1a), and when averaging EXAFS data, agreement was found with XRPD (that works at higher symmetry). The octahedron diagonal (R Zr2) showed good agreement between XRPD and ab initio, while EXAFS alone was able to detect the splitting of the diagonals (Figure 8c).
elements.clean_text: Dehydroxylated case: For XRPD, three equivalent Rμ3-O exist that well matched with ab initio results (able to take into complete account the symmetry breaking of the system). In this case, EXAFS saw only two out of three μ3-O distances that, nevertheless, agreed very nicely with the calculated one; the remaining R μ3-O laid in the range of the four oxygen atoms of the carboxylate units, leading to an average value slightly smaller than those obtained with XRPD and ab initio approaches that agreed better. Coming to the metallic distances, ab initio and EXAFS, both were able to observe the splitting of the octahedron edges and agreed on the long value (R Zr1b), while they disagreed on the shorter one (R Zr1a), and when averaging EXAFS data, agreement was found with XRPD (that works at higher symmetry). The octahedron diagonal (R Zr2) showed good agreement between XRPD and ab initio, while EXAFS alone was able to detect the splitting of the diagonals (Figure 8c).

elements.content: Experimental IR spectra were obtained upon solvent removal, progressive dehydration, and successive rehydration to compare the differences in the vibrational behavior of the two structures. Calculated spectra were also computed and used to determine unambiguously the nature of the vibrational modes through the use of animations. In general, a good agreement both in position and in the intensity of the peaks was found between the two approaches. As expected, the main changes between hydroxylated and dehydroxylated forms are due to the Zr6O4(OH)4 cluster that rearranges into a distorted Zr6O6 one upon activation. In particular, the band at 470 cm−1 due to the (HO)−Zr−(OH) bending mode disappears, and the band at 672 cm−1, associated to the μ3−O stretching, shifts to 730 cm−1 in case of the dehydroxylated material. IR results confirmed the high stability of the material with respect to water solvent, showing complete reversibility of the dehydration/hydration phenomenon.
elements.clean_text: Experimental IR spectra were obtained upon solvent removal, progressive dehydration, and successive rehydration to compare the differences in the vibrational behavior of the two structures. Calculated spectra were also computed and used to determine unambiguously the nature of the vibrational modes through the use of animations. In general, a good agreement both in position and in the intensity of the peaks was found between the two approaches. As expected, the main changes between hydroxylated and dehydroxylated forms are due to the Zr6O4(OH)4 cluster that rearranges into a distorted Zr6O6 one upon activation. In particular, the band at 470 cm-1 due to the (HO)-Zr-(OH) bending mode disappears, and the band at 672 cm-1, associated to the μ3-O stretching, shifts to 730 cm-1 in case of the dehydroxylated material. IR results confirmed the high stability of the material with respect to water solvent, showing complete reversibility of the dehydration/hydration phenomenon.

elements.content: A good agreement was also observed between band gaps obtained by UV−vis spectra and ab initio calculations. The materials are characterized by an absorption edge due to π−π* electronic transitions of the aromatic ring, and sample activation induces a small blue shift of the edge that moves from 4.07 to 3.94 eV (trend confirmed by the values calculated at 4.56 and 4.19 eV, respectively).
elements.clean_text: A good agreement was also observed between band gaps obtained by UV-vis spectra and ab initio calculations. The materials are characterized by an absorption edge due to π-π* electronic transitions of the aromatic ring, and sample activation induces a small blue shift of the edge that moves from 4.07 to 3.94 eV (trend confirmed by the values calculated at 4.56 and 4.19 eV, respectively).

elements.content: In conclusion, this work shows the necessity to combine, in an interactive and synergic way, different experimental techniques with periodic ab initio calculations to disclose and fully understand the nature of complex novel materials such as UiO-66 on structural, vibrational, and electronics grounds. None of the three adopted techniques would be able to alone disclose the hydroxylated or the dehydroxylated structure. The hydroxylated structure was solved by XRPD Rietveld analysis in the Fm-3m space group. However, because of the poor quality of the fit, this structure needed to be confirmed by EXAFS and ab initio approaches. The structure of the dehydroxylated material, obtained from a high quality Rietveld refinement (Figure ; Rwp = 0.022) was unable to detect the distortion of the Zr6O6 octahedron (striking in the EXAFS datum, Figure c) and provides an input for the ab initio calculation that was not leading to a stable minimum. The lower symmetry system obtained from the ab initio calculation allowed a 3-D structure to be obtained that was used as input for a detailed EXAFS refinement. The latter evidenced a further symmetry reduction due to a significant splitting of the Zr6O6 octahedron diagonals.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, this work shows the necessity to combine, in an interactive and synergic way, different experimental techniques with periodic ab initio calculations to disclose and fully understand the nature of complex novel materials such as UiO-66 on structural, vibrational, and electronics grounds. None of the three adopted techniques would be able to alone disclose the hydroxylated or the dehydroxylated structure. The hydroxylated structure was solved by XRPD Rietveld analysis in the Fm-3m space group. However, because of the poor quality of the fit, this structure needed to be confirmed by EXAFS and ab initio approaches. The structure of the dehydroxylated material, obtained from a high quality Rietveld refinement (Figure ; Rwp = 0.022) was unable to detect the distortion of the Zr6O6 octahedron (striking in the EXAFS datum, Figure c) and provides an input for the ab initio calculation that was not leading to a stable minimum. The lower symmetry system obtained from the ab initio calculation allowed a 3-D structure to be obtained that was used as input for a detailed EXAFS refinement. The latter evidenced a further symmetry reduction due to a significant splitting of the Zr6O6 octahedron diagonals.

elements.content:
At the moment, work is in progress to extend this approach to isoreticular versions of UiO-66 such as UiO-67 and UiO-68 and to some linker functionalized forms.

BET nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms of UiO-66 at 77 K; XRPD pattern of desolvated UiO-66 after interaction with water, benzene, acetone, ethanol, DMF, ethanol, HCl, H2O, and NaOH; CIF file for the hydroxylated structure obtained from XRPD Rietveld refinement in the Fm-3m space group; CRYSTAL input files for both structures; adopted Zirconium Basis-Set; and BET curve. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.content: The amplitude factor is defined as S 0 2 = |<Y i N−1∥Y f N−1>|2, where Y i N−1 and Y f N−1 are the many-body wave functions of the “passive” electrons (those of the adsorbing atom that are not photoexcited) before and after excitation of the “active” electron. The value of this amplitude reduction factor should usually be between 0.7 and 0.9; however, because of the known incertitude of EXAFS in determining the exact coordination number N, its S 0 2 may result slightly greater than unit in some practical cases.
elements.clean_text:
References

The amplitude factor is defined as S 0 2 = |<Y i  N-1∥Y f  N-1>|2, where Y i  N-1 and Y f  N-1 are the many-body wave functions of the "passive" electrons (those of the adsorbing atom that are not photoexcited) before and after excitation of the "active" electron. The value of this amplitude reduction factor should usually be between 0.7 and 0.9; however, because of the known incertitude of EXAFS in determining the exact coordination number N, its S 0 2 may result slightly greater than unit in some practical cases.

elements.content: In the preliminary EXAFS refinement reported in Table 1, we observe that the Zr−O distance at 2.232 Å is 6-fold degenerate. Once a more accurate model is used to refine the structure, we will realize that it corresponds to the sum of a Zr−μ3OH (degeneration = 4) and a Zr−O1 distance of the corboxylate units (degeneration = 2) that are too close to be resolved by EXAFS.

cln_elements.content: Temperature-dependent XRPD investigation indicates that the UiO-66 framework is stable in air up to 375 °C (Figure a). No changes of the XRPD pattern are appreciable until structure collapse. We performed a parallel TGA/MS experiment in order to (i) confirm XRPD results, (ii) learn about the temperature needed to remove the solvent, and (iii) understand the chemical nature of the fragments formed upon framework collapse. The TGA curve reported in panel (b) of Figure exhibits a progressive structured weight loss up to 300 °C, with a clear shoulder around 100 °C. MS spectroscopy, panels (c) and (d) of Figure , shows that the sample is loosing physisorbed water first and DMF molecules afterward. In the 300−500 °C interval, a stability plateau at 71.5% of the starting weight is observed. In the successive 50 °C, there is a significant weight loss, and the sample is left with the 35.5% of the starting weight. XRPD testifies the crystallinity up to 375 °C, with subsequent amorphization of the structure and pore collapse. Loss of benzene fragments starts around 500 °C and is over already at 550 °C. The residual material at the end of the TGA experiment is simply ZrO2, with a very low degree of crystallinity.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Structure Stability upon Thermal Treatment

Temperature-dependent XRPD investigation indicates that the UiO-66 framework is stable in air up to 375 °C (Figure a). No changes of the XRPD pattern are appreciable until structure collapse. We performed a parallel TGA/MS experiment in order to (i) confirm XRPD results, (ii) learn about the temperature needed to remove the solvent, and (iii) understand the chemical nature of the fragments formed upon framework collapse. The TGA curve reported in panel (b) of Figure  exhibits a progressive structured weight loss up to 300 °C, with a clear shoulder around 100 °C. MS spectroscopy, panels (c) and (d) of Figure , shows that the sample is loosing physisorbed water first and DMF molecules afterward. In the 300-500 °C interval, a stability plateau at 71.5% of the starting weight is observed. In the successive 50 °C, there is a significant weight loss, and the sample is left with the 35.5% of the starting weight. XRPD testifies the crystallinity up to 375 °C, with subsequent amorphization of the structure and pore collapse. Loss of benzene fragments starts around 500 °C and is over already at 550 °C. The residual material at the end of the TGA experiment is simply ZrO2, with a very low degree of crystallinity.

data.condition: left with the 35.5% of the starting weight

EXAFS refinement was obtained using as input model the optimized structure from XRPD and from ab initio calculations for the hydroxylated and dehydroxylated forms, respectively. With this approach the coordination number (N) of each contribution is fixed by the model stoichiometry; such values are reported for each shell in parentheses. Refinement of the experimental amplitude is done by optimizing the overall amplitude factor S 0 2 only. For the dehydroxylated form, the fitting of the higher shells was possible only by adopting the axial compressed model of the Zr6O6 octahedron represented in panel (c) of Figure , where twelve octahedron sides R Zr1 are split into eight short prismatic distances (R Zr1a, N = 8/3) and four long planar ones (R Zr1b, N = 4/3) and where the three diagonals R Zr2 are split into a short axial diagonal and (R Zr2a, involving two Zr atoms out of six; N = 1/3) and two long planar diagonals (R Zr2b, involving four Zr atoms out of six; N = 2/3). The quality of the fits can be appreciated looking to Figures 6 and 9 for the hydroxylated and dehydroxylated forms of UiO-66, respectively.

cln_elements.content: Structure of UiO-66 MOF. (a): Representation of a super tetrahedron cage. (b): Representation of a super octahedron cage. (c): Combination of one octahedral cage and two adjacent tetrahedral cages forming a cubic unit consisting of eight inorganic Zr6O4(OH)4 bricks. Zirconium, oxygen, carbon, and hydrogen atoms are represented in red, blue, gray, and white, respectively. Yellow arrows indicate the squeezing direction that the Zr6O6 octahedron undergoes after the dehydroxylation process (Section 4.3). Yellow circles represent arrows pointing toward the reader. For each Zr6O6 octahedron, this direction randomly coincides with one out of its three diagonals.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Structure of UiO-66 MOF. (a): Representation of a super tetrahedron cage. (b): Representation of a super octahedron cage. For each Zr6O6 octahedron, this direction randomly coincides with one out of its three diagonals.

cln_elements.content: High-temperature part of the TGA curves of UiO-66 samples synthesized in different batches. For all curves, the ordinate axis was normalized to 100 for the solid residual at high temperature, corresponding to ZrO2, gray horizontal line. In this scale, the dehydrated, desolvated UiO-66 should have a stoichiometry of ZrO(CO2)2(C6H4), corresponding to a normalized weight of 235.7 (black horizontal line). The horizontal bold arrow represents the expected weight loss for an ideal UiO-66 material characterized by 12 BDC linkers per Zr6O4(OH)4 octahedron. Experimental curves, reporting a lower weight loss (see vertical arrows with the same line code) at this stage testify of the presence of framework defectivity: linker vacancies.

cln_elements.content: (a): Stick and ball representation of the dehydroxylation undergone by the inorganic Zr6O4(OH)4 cluster upon thermal treatment at 300 °C in vacuo resulting in a distorted Zr6O6 cluster. Red, blue, and cyan colors refer to Zr, O, and H atoms, respectively. (b): Stick and ball representation of the perfect Zr6 octahedron, showing 12 equivalent R Zr1 sides and thee equivalent R Zr2 = (2 R Zr1)1/2 diagonals. (c): Stick and ball representation of a squeezed Zr6 octahedron. The 12 sides are now split into four in-plane long R Zr1b sides and eight prismatic short R Zr1a sides, while the three diagonals evolve into two in-plane long R Zr2b and one orthogonal short R Zr2a diagonals. For clarity, O and H atoms are omitted in panels (b) and (c).

cln_elements.content: (a): Comparison between experimental (scattered squares) and best fit (full line) k3-weighted χ(k) of the dehydroxylated UiO-66 material. (b): As panel (a) in R-space (both moduli and imaginary parts are reported). The 3-D structure obtained from the ab initio optimization, performed at B3LYP level, in the R3̅ space group was used as input model for the EXAFS refinement, with the only exceptions of the two R Zr contributions. The fitting of the shorter R Zr1a and R Zr1b distances is done fixing the EXAFS coordination numbers to 8/3 and 4/3, respectively (being 2 the degeneration in the ab initio calculations). The fitting of the longer R Zr2 distance (three diagonals of the Zr6 octahedron) could be possible only splitting the contribution into a short axial diagonal and (R Zr2a, involving two Zr atoms out of six; N = 1/3) and two long diagonals (R Zr2b, involving four Zr atoms out of six; N = 2/3).

metadata.title: Disclosing the Complex Structure of UiO-66 Metal Organic Framework: A Synergic Combination of Experiment and Theory
